scpub1.translation_process: Translated from the Pali. Primary source was the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, with reference to several English translations, especially those of K.R. Norman.
scpub1.translation_description: This translation aims to make a clear, readable, and accurate rendering of the Theragāthā. The initial edition was by Jessica Walton and Bhikkhu Sujato was published in 2014 through SuttaCentral. A revised edition, bringing the terminology in line with the subsequently-translated four Nikāyas, was published in 2019.

license.license_statement: This translation is an expression of an ancient spiritual text that has been passed down by the Buddhist tradition for the benefit of all sentient beings. It is dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation. The translator respectfully requests that any use be in accordance with the values and principles of the Buddhist community.

scpub2.translation_subtitle: A translation of the Dīgha Nikāya
scpub2.translation_process: Primary source was the digital Mahāsaṅgīti edition of the Pali Tipiṭaka. Translated from the Pali, with reference to several English translations, especially those of Bhikkhu Bodhi.
scpub2.translation_description: This translation was part of a project to translate the four Pali Nikāyas with the following aims: plain, approachable English; consistent terminology; accurate rendition of the Pali; free of copyright. It was made during 2016–2018 while Bhikkhu Sujato was staying in Qimei, Tawian.

scpub6.translation_process: Primary source was the digital Mahāsaṅgīti edition of the Pali Tipiṭaka. Translated from the Pali, with reference to several English translations, especially those of K.R. Norman.
scpub6.translation_description: This translation aims to make a clear, readable, and accurate rendering of the Therīgāthā. The initial draft was by Jessica Walton, and it was completed by Bhikkhu Sujato in 2019. The terminology has been brought in line with Bhikkhu Sujato’s translation of the four Nikāyas.

license.license_statement: This translation is an expression of an ancient spiritual text that has been passed down by the Buddhist tradition for the benefit of all sentient beings. scpub8.translation_subtitle: A translation of the Pali Vinaya Piṭaka into English
scpub8.translation_process: Translated from the Pali. Primary source was the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, with occasional reference of other Pali editions, especially the Chaṭṭha Saṅgāyana edition and the Pali Text Society edition. I cross-checked with I.B. Horner’s English translation, “The Book of the Discipline”, as well Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita’s “A Translation and Analysis of the Pātimokkha” and Ajahn Ṭhānissaro’s “Buddhist Monastic Code”.
scpub8.translation_description: This is the first complete translation of the Vinaya Piṭaka in English. The aim has been to produce a translation that is easy to read, clear, and accurate, and also modern in vocabulary and style.

license.license_statement: This translation is an expression of an ancient spiritual text that has been passed down by the Buddhist tradition for the benefit of all sentient beings. It is dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation. The translator respectfully requests that any use be in accordance with the values and principles of the Buddhist community.

scpub9.translation_process: Die ursprüngliche Quelle ist die digitale Mahāsaṅgīti-Ausgabe des Pali-Tipiṭaka. Die Übersetzung stützt sich sehr stark auf Bhikkhu Sujatos englische Übersetzung, bestehende deutsche Übersetzungen, insbesondere die von Bhikkhu Mettiko, werden zu Referenzzwecken ebenfalls herangezogen.
scpub9.translation_description: Diese Übersetzung ist Teil eines Projekts, die vier Pali-Nikāyas ins Deutsche zu übersetzen. Die Übersetzung geht von Bhikkhu Sujatos englischer Übersetzung aus, wie sie auf SuttaCentral publiziert ist. Die Ziele des Projekts sind: einfaches, leicht verständliches Deutsch; einheitliche Terminologie; möglichst genaue Wiedergabe des Pali entsprechend Bhikkhu Sujatos Übersetzung; kein Copyright. Das Projekt wurde in der zweiten Hälfte von 2019 begonnen und ist noch nicht abgeschlossen.
scpub9.publication_status: Diese Übersetzung ist vorläufig und unterliegt weiterer Bearbeitung.

scpub20.translation_subtitle: A Translation of the Chinese Saṃyukta Āgama
scpub20.translation_process: The Related Discourses is translated directly from classical Chinese using Yinshun’s 雜阿含經論會編 as the root text while consulting the Taisho Daizokyo (T 99) and CBETA editions and parallels found in Chinese, Pali, and Sanskrit. English translations consulted include translations of SĀ sutras by Bhikkhu Anālayo as well as English translations of the Pali Nikāyas by Bhikkhu Sujato and Bhikkhu Bodhi.
scpub20.translation_description: This translation is part of Charles Patton’s Dharma Pearls Project to translate Chinese EBTs into modern English and provide them free to the public. This project began in 2019 and is an ongoing work-in-progress.
scpub20.publication_status: This is an ongoing translation project in its early stage. Translations of individual sutras are initially released at Dharma Pearls and mirrored at SuttaCentral.

license.license_statement: This translation is an expression of an ancient spiritual text that has been passed down by the Buddhist tradition for the benefit of all sentient beings. It is dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation. The translator respectfully requests that any use be in accordance with the values and principles of the Buddhist community.

scpub35.translation_subtitle: A Translation of the Chinese Madhyama Āgama
scpub35.translation_process: The Medium Discourses is translated directly from classical Chinese using the CBETA edition (T 26) as the root text while consulting parallels found in Chinese, Pali, and Sanskrit. English translations consulted include translations of MĀ sutras by Bhikkhu Anālayo, et al as well as English translations of the Pali Nikāyas by Bhikkhu Sujato and Bhikkhu Bodhi.
scpub35.translation_description: This translation is part of Charles Patton’s Dharma Pearls Project to translate Chinese EBTs into modern English and provide them free to the public. This project began in 2019 and is an ongoing work-in-progress.
scpub35.publication_status: This is an ongoing translation project in its early stage. Translations of individual sutras are initially released at Dharma Pearls and mirrored at SuttaCentral.

scpub36.translation_subtitle: A Translation of the Chinese Ekôttarika Āgama
scpub36.translation_process: The Numerical Discourses is translated directly from classical Chinese using the CBETA edition (T 125) as the root text while consulting parallels found in Chinese, Pali, and Sanskrit. English translations consulted include translations of EĀ sutras by Bhikkhu Anālayo, et al as well as English translations of the Pali Nikāyas by Bhikkhu Sujato and Bhikkhu Bodhi.
scpub36.translation_description: This translation is part of Charles Patton’s Dharma Pearls Project to translate Chinese EBTs into modern English and provide them free to the public. This project began in 2019 and is an ongoing work-in-progress.
scpub36.publication_status: This is an ongoing translation project in its early stage. Translations of individual sutras are initially released at Dharma Pearls and mirrored at SuttaCentral.

scpub37.translation_subtitle: A Translation of the Chinese Dīrgha Āgama
scpub37.translation_process: The Long Discourses is translated directly from classical Chinese using the CBETA edition (T 1) as the root text while consulting parallels found in Chinese, Pali, and Sanskrit. English translations consulted include translations of DĀ sutras by Bhikkhu Anālayo and Shohei Ichimura as well as translations of the Pali Nikāyas by Bhikkhu Sujato and Bhikkhu Bodhi.
scpub37.translation_description: This translation is part of Charles Patton’s Dharma Pearls Project to translate Chinese EBTs into modern English and provide them free to the public. This project began in 2019 and is an ongoing work-in-progress.
scpub37.publication_status: This is an ongoing translation project in its early stage. Translations of individual sutras are initially released at Dharma Pearls and mirrored at SuttaCentral.

scpub38.author_name: The M.L. Maniratana Bunnag Dhamma Society Fund
scpub38.translation_subtitle: World Tipiṭaka Edition in Roman Script
scpub38.translation_process: The Chaṭṭha Saṅgāyana edition was proofread three times visually and three times orally, and checked against over a dozen printed editions.
scpub38.translation_description: Edited and published by The M.L. Maniratana Bunnag Dhamma Society Fund, 2005. Based on the digital edition of the Chaṭṭha Saṅgāyana published by the Vipassana Research Institute, with corrections and proofreading by the Dhamma Society. Prepared for SuttaCentral by Blake Walshe and Bhikkhu Sujato.
scpub38.publication_status: Completed. The original project is dissolved, and SuttaCentral aims to preserve the Mahāsaṅgīti exactly, without making any edits or corrections to the text. SuttaCentral has, however, made a few corrections to punctuation, and have adapted the text to the Bilara JSON format.

scpub39.author_name: Chinese Buddhist Electronic Text Association (中華電子佛典協會)
scpub39.translation_process: CBETA describes their process of selecting, inputting, formatting, and editing texts on their website.
scpub39.translation_description: CBETA is an ongoing digitization project that consists of a consortium of Chinese Buddhist and academic organizations initially formed in 1998 for the purpose of creating an electronic edition of Chinese Buddhist texts. The project has input and normalized classical Chinese Buddhist canonical sources such as the Taishō Shinshū Daizōkyō and Shinsan Zakuzokyo and modern works such as those by Ven. Yinshun.
scpub39.publication_status: This is an on-going project that periodically publishes and updates texts in various formats such as CD-ROM discs and e-books. They also maintain a web publication called CBETA Online.

scpub40.translation_title: Taishō Shinshū Daizōkyō (大正新脩大藏經)
scpub40.translation_process: The editors documented variant readings and included supplements such as ancient fragments discovered at Dunhuang. The SAT digitization project has corrected errors and worked with the Unicode Consortium to add rare Chinese characters missing from UTF encoding so that they can be displayed in future electronic editions.
scpub40.translation_description: The Taishō Shinshū Daizōkyō is a critical edition of the Chinese Buddhist canon based on previous official editions dating back to 971 CE.
scpub40.publication_status: The print edition of the Taishō Shinshū Daizōkyō was originally published in Japan between 1924-1934 in 100 vols. The SAT digitization project holds the copyright to the Taishō and has published an official electronic edition (SAT Daizōkyō Text Database) which is periodically updated.

scpub41.translation_subtitle: A Combined Edition of the Saṁyuktāgama and Commentary
scpub41.translation_process: Yìnshùn critically edited the Saṁyuktāgama using a variety of sources found in Chinese and Pali. He reordering the fascicles of the Taishō edition (T 99), which scholars had concluded were disordered at some point in the past, and added headings for the vargas and individual saṁyuktas described in Sarvâstivāda sources. He also removed material that was originally a separate translation of Jātaka literature, and he renumbered the sutras in the collection by counting all of the abbreviated sutras described in the original translator’s notes.
scpub41.translation_description: A corrected edition of the Saṁyuktāgama (T 99) with commentary extracted from Xuánzàng’s translation of the Yogâcārabhūmi śāstra (T 1579).
